body: Can not reproduce, did you set your `scroll_history` to something massive?
In `alacritty.yml`? I don't have a key with that name; does it default to something huge?
Not really, it should default to `10000`, but you can try to set it to `1` to see if it fixes this.
I've also seen that `resize` is inside your backtrace, maybe that has something to do with it. Like your window manager might temporarily tell alacritty to get massive?

You can try running `RUST_LOG=info cargo run` and check if there's something odd in the output. It should print the resolution of the window when resizing, so make sure there's no ridiculously big window value in there.

The log output is:

```
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty: Welcome to Alacritty.
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty: Configuration loaded from /home/ringo025/.config/alacritty/alacritty.yml
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::display: device_pixel_ratio: 1
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::renderer: width: 1916, height: 497
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::display: Initializing glyph cache
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::display: Finished initializing glyph cache in 0.041887507
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::renderer: width: 4, height: 460
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::display: Cell Size: (4294967300 x 19)
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty: PTY Dimensions: Line(24) x Column(0)
 INFO 2018-03-09T19:28:54Z: alacritty::renderer: Font size changed: Size(24)
```

The `Cell Size: (4294967300 x 19)` is suspect...
You could probably see those cells from space, no surprise it's trying to allocate so much memory. This is definitely the issue.
What would it make sense for that to be? I do have `Xft.dpi: 96` in my `.Xresources`, if that'd be a potential cause.
@remexre can you try running in a debug build? It looks like there's a u32 overflow happening, and it should panic in the debug build.
Oh, and Alacritty doesn't read _.Xresources_.
Those are all from debug builds; there's no panic.

Sorry it took so long to test this, I can only reproduce the bug on my work machine. Looks like it's offset:

```
Advance: 10
Offset: 4294967284
```
@remexre what is the unaltered `font.offset().x`?
unaltered? You mean without the `f64::from() as u32` bits? `-12`, which I'm just now realizing this machine doesn't need (although my laptop does, for some reason)

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/10184

This is currently UB in Rust. The best fix for this would probably be restricting `font.offset.x` to `u32`.

I actually use negative offset on my laptop and home desktop though -- for some reason, [Nerd Fonts](https://github.com/ryanoasis/nerd-fonts) require an X offset equal to the negation of the font size. (i.e. `font.offset.x = -font.size`)

I can open a separate issue for that if that's not already a known-bug with... something involving fullwidth vs. halfwidth? idk

The fullwidth vs halfwidth bug should have been fixed in 59b561b440060e7b0d13160fb69519d127e6c687.

However the general concept of negatively offsetting the font width should still be possible, it should just be restricted to be at least the size of the average advance, so that the cell width is at least 0 or 1.

I'll look into this a bit more, but we might have to make this a runtime check.

I don't think it's (**EDIT**: it's = the fix is) working on Arch Linux, then.

All copies of alacritty are being built from a0b55ca with Rust 1.24.1, so I'm not sure why the work desktop doesn't say so in `alacritty --version` (or even `cargo run -- --version`).
a0b55ca8da2e39f71edeeec66d9e58633f756b16 does not have the PR merged I've mentioned.
Oh. Then idk how `git branch --contains` works. :P
Since it is possible to reproduce this issue on master, I'm removing the Scrollback label. I've opened a PR to fix this. I don't think on master it allocates a ton of memory though.

issue.title: Prevent negative cell dimensions
issue.body:
Prevent the cell dimensions from going below 1, this bug resulted in
allocation of large amounts of memory in the scrollback PR but is also
present on master.

Currently the approach is to just `panic!`, however an `eprintln!` and
`exit` could be an alternative too. I don't think it's realistic to
check this at startup and it should have no performance impact since the
failing method is only called once at startup.

To make it a bit more clear what kind of values are accepted, the
datatypes of offsets and paddings have also been changed so that these
don't accept floats anymore and padding can never be negative.

This should allow us to be a bit more strict with the config to make
sure that errors are printed when invalid values are specified (like
negative padding).

This fixes #1167.
